{{Use Indian English|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Ship Of Theseus | image = File:Ship_of_Theseus_domestic_release_poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Anand Gandhi]] | screenplay = Anand Gandhi | story = Anand Gandhi
Khushboo Ranka | producer = [[Sohum Shah (actor)|Sohum Shah]]
Mukesh Shah
Amita Shah | starring = [[Aida Al-Khashef]]
Neeraj Kabi
Sohum Shah | music = [[Benedict Taylor (musician)|Benedict Taylor]]
Naren Chandavarkar
| cinematography = Pankaj Kumar | editing = Adesh Prasad
Sanyukta Kaza
Satchit Puranik | production design = Pooja Shetty
Rakesh Yadav | studio = Recyclewala Films | distributor = [[UTV Motion Pictures]]
Fortissimo FIlms | released = {{film date|2012|9|6|[[2012 Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|df=yes|2013|7|19|India}} | runtime = 143 minutes | country = [[India]] | language = [[English language|English]]
[[Hindi]]
[[Arabic language|Arabic]]
[[Swedish language|Swedish]] | Executive Producer = Mitesh Shah
Ruchi Bhimani }} '''''Ship of Theseus''''' is a 2013 [[India]]n [[drama film]] written and directed by [[Anand Gandhi]], and produced by actor [[Sohum Shah]]. The film explores "questions of identity, justice, beauty, meaning and death through the stories of an experimental photographer, an ailing monk and an enterprising stockbroker", played by Aida El-Kashef, Neeraj Kabi and Sohum Shah. After three years in development, the film premiered at the [[2012 Toronto International Film Festival]], where it received critical acclaim{{cite news|last=Dixon|first=Guy|title=TIFF movie review: Ship of Theseus|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/tiff/tiff-reviews/tiff-movie-review-ship-of-theseus/article4524327/|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=6 September 2012}}{{cite journal|last=D'Arcy|first=David|title=Ship Of Theseus |journal=Screen Daily|date=8 September 2012|url=http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/the-latest/ship-of-theseus/5046305.article}} and was touted as "the hidden gem of the year".{{cite journal|last=Wadera|first=Guneet|title=Ship of Theseus – Cameron Baileys hidden gem from Mumbai|journal=Filmi Cafe|date=20 Aug 2012|url=http://www.filmicafe.co/news/Ship-of-Theseus---Cameron-Baileys-hidden-gem-from-Mumbai}} It has received positive reviews from both Indian and international press{{cite journal|last=Vroman|first=Nicholas|title=FESTIVALS: PIA FILM FESTIVAL & TOKYO INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL|date=14 Nov 2012|url=http://www.filmcomment.com/entry/festivals-pia-film-festival-tokyo-international-film-festival}} and has been hailed as "the most significant film to come out of India in a very long time".{{cite news|last=Kamath|first=Sudhish|title= Desi ship on a world tour|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-cinemaplus/desi-ship-on-a-world-tour/article4131836.ece|newspaper=The Hindu|date=25 Nov 2012}} Film critic [[Derek Malcolm]] has called it a "life-changing film" and ''Variety'' commended its "unexpected grandeur". The title of the film alludes to [[Ship of Theseus|Theseus’ paradox]], most notably recorded in "[[Parallel Lives|Life of Theseus]]", wherein the [[Greek philosopher|Greek historian and philosopher]] [[Plutarch]] inquires whether a ship that has been restored by replacing all its parts remains the same ship. The film released in India on 19 July 2013.{{cite journal| author=News Desk | title=Kiran Rao to present "Ship of Theseus", set to release on July 19 | journal=Dear Cinema | date=14 May 2013}} It won the award for the [[National Film Award for Best Feature Film|Best Feature Film]] of the year at the [[61st National Film Awards]]. ==Plot== Aaliya Kamal ([[Aida El-Kashef]]) is a visually impaired and celebrated Egyptian photographer in the process of undergoing a [[cornea transplant]] that will restore her vision. Though the surgery is a success and Aaliya’s vision is restored, she has trouble adjusting to her new found sense of sight and is dissatisfied with her resulting photography. Maitreya ([[Neeraj Kabi]]), an erudite [[Jainism|Jain]] monk, is part of a petition to ban [[animal testing]] in India. When he is diagnosed with liver [[cirrhosis]], his reluctance towards animal-tested medication is questioned and he must now depend on the people he’s been fighting against – a path he refuses to take. A young Indian stockbroker, Navin (Sohum Shah), has just received a [[new kidney]]. He soon learns of a case of [[organ theft]] involving an impoverished bricklayer, Shankar. He initially fears that his new kidney was the one stolen from Shankar. When he learns that the recipient of the [[kidney]] lives in Sweden, he decides to go there to help Shankar get his kidney back – but is Shankar perhaps better helped by a large financial settlement instead of having two kidneys again? Ship of Theseus ends with the [[Allegory of the Cave|Platonic Allegory of the cave]]. The philosopher Plato argues that human beings are imprisoned in the cave of their own existence, falsely believing the temporary as having permanence. The job of a philosopher, he argues, is to help people find a way out of the cave. In the last scene of the film, we see the shadow of the man in the walls of the cave he is exploring. Those who received his organs (including Aaliya, Maitreya and Navin) watch this short clip. The man who we see only as the shadow in this clip did not make it out of the allegorical prison-cave described by Plato. ==Main cast== {{Div col}} * [[Aida El-Kashef]] as Aliya Kamal * [[Neeraj Kabi]] as Maitreya * [[Sohum Shah (actor)|Sohum Shah]] as Navin Parnami * [[Amba Sanyal]] as Bhanu Ajji * [[Faraz Khan]] as Vinay * [[Vinay Shukla]] as Charvaka * Sameer Khurana as Mannu * Sunip Sen as Lawyer Gupta * Kirti Munshi as Lawyer * Vipul Binjola as Jagannath * Ramnik Parekh as Dr. Bhargava * Sunip Sen as Sunip * Manoj Shah as Shantimuni * Yashwant Wasnik as Shankar * [[Saar Kashyap]] as Street Play Actor {{Div col end}} ==Production== ===Development=== Anand Gandhi conceived the story while he was nursing his ailing grandparents at the hospital.{{cite news|last=Ramnath|first=Nandini|title=Transcendental meditation|url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/1FEDTk4Aho3qJ3WGTnSpTI/Transcendental-meditation.html|date=14 Dec 2012}} It was here that he developed stories addressing the idea of the self, change and death. Through the ailing monk and the socially incognizant stockbroker, Gandhi and co-story writer Khushboo Ranka discussed questions of non-violence, altruism and responsibility. On cinematographer Pankaj Kumar’s suggestion, they developed the parallel story of a visually impaired photographer, who struggles with her revived sight following a cornea transplant. Gandhi spent the year after that developing the screenplay. With a screenplay in hand, he set out to meet several producers – both independent and eminent. However, producing the film was usually perceived as a challenge, owing to prejudices about the commercial viability of an Indian film, dealing in such subject matter. Eventually, actor Sohum Shah decided to step in as the producer of the film, "to safeguard the artistic integrity of the project".{{cite web|last=Tuteja|first=Joginder|title=What made actor Sohum Shah produce SHIP OF THESEUS?|url=http://www.glamsham.com/movies/scoops/12/nov/23-news-what-made-actor-sohum-shah-produce-ship-of-theseus-111203.asp|publisher=glamsham.com/|accessdate=23 November 2012}} ===Casting=== Anand first met Egyptian filmmaker Aida El-Kashef in 2008, at the Hannover Film Festival where their respective short films – 'Continuum’ (which Gandhi had co-directed with Khushboo Ranka) and 'Rhapsody in Autumn’ – were being screened.{{cite web|title=u-a-c award winner's first feature film to be released soon|url=http://www.up-and-coming.de/News.71.0.html?&no_cache=1&L=1&tx_ttnews[tt_news]=202|publisher=International Film Festival Hannover|date=2 November 2010}} The following year, Aida assisted Anand with the casting of the film. Her reading of the photographer’s lines, while auditioning actors for the character of the boyfriend, motivated Gandhi and DP Pankaj Kumar to cast her in the role. The character was subsequently re-written to accommodate her background and ethnicity.{{cite journal|last=Dutta|first=Nandita|title=Anand Gandhi on his debut "Ship of Theseus"|journal=Dear Cinema|date=22 October 2012}} Neeraj Kabi, a Mumbai-based theatre actor and director, was considered for the role of Maitreya from the outset. Gandhi and Kabi discussed the character in detail, and rehearsed for a few months, prior to principal photography. Sohum Shah met Gandhi through a mutual friend, and was chosen for the role of Navin in the stockbroker story, along with his friend and ally, Sameer Khurana (aka Mannu). Eventually, Shah found himself drawn to Gandhi’s story and vision, and came on board as the producer of the film as well.{{cite journal|last=Earnshaw|first=Helen|title=Anand Gandhi Talks About Ship Of Theseus – LFF 2012 |journal=Female First|date=18 October 2012|url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/movies/Anand+Gandhi+Interview-262183.html}} A lot of non-actors and friends were cast to play secondary and passing parts. Sunip Sengupta is a real-life lawyer. Vinay Shukla playing the young law intern Charvaka is a filmmaker, and Megha Ramaswamy, playing the interviewer, is a writer-producer. [[Paromita Vohra]], a feminist documentary filmmaker, makes an appearance as well. ===Filming=== The film was shot over a period of two years on a [[Canon EOS-1D Mark IV]],{{cite web|title=Ship of Theseus Technical Specifications|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1773764/technical|publisher=imdb.com}} along with a Redrock Micro rig and a lot of guerilla techniques developed by DP Pankaj Kumar. Most of the film was shot on location in and around [[Mumbai]], in [[Jaipur]], [[Chitkul|Chhitkul]] ([[Himachal Pradesh]]) and also included a brief schedule in [[Stockholm]].{{cite web|title=Filming Locations|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1773764/locations|publisher=imdb.com}} While shooting outside of Mumbai, the production unit generally consisted of a three-person crew, with each multi-tasking in various capacities. For the Stockholm shoot, Gandhi connected with Rupesh Tillu, a theatre and clown artist based in the city. Tillu handled production and helped the team connect with actors and scout locations. He also played the role of Ajay, Navin’s friend in Stockholm.{{cite web|title=Rupesh Tillu|url=http://filmbasen.se/filmare/rupesh-tillu|publisher=Film Basen}} To portray the ailing physical condition of Maitreya, Kabi lost close to 17 kilos (37.5 pounds, approx.) over four months, through a rigorous diet and exercise routine.{{cite journal|last=Ayaz|first=Shaikh|title=The Man with Many Questions|journal=Open Magazine|date=3 November 2012|url=http://www.openthemagazine.com/article/cinema/the-man-with-many-questions}} Through this period, Kabi’s fragile state deterred him from taking on any additional acting or theatre work. Gandhi also collaborated with [[Budapest]]-based [[Sound Designer]], Gabor Erdelyi, who had earlier worked on some of [[Bela Tarr]]’s films, including ''[[The Turin Horse]]''.{{cite journal|author=Variety Staff|title=Review: "Ship of Theseus"|journal=Variety|date=5 February 2013|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/ship-of-theseus-1117949172/}} ==Release== ===Sales=== A work-in-progress version of the film was screened in the Film Bazaar in Goa in 2011. This is where Netherlands-based film sales company, Fortissimo Films, picked up world sales rights to the film.{{cite journal|last=Shackleton|first=Liz|title=Fortissimo boards Ship Of Theseus|journal=Screen Daily|date=27 November 2011|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/asia-pacific/fortissimo-boards-ship-of-theseus/5035083.article}} ===Festival screenings=== The film premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival in September 2012, and has subsequently been screened at the Tokyo International Film Festival,{{cite web|last=Vroman|first=Nicholas|title=[Interview] Competition "Ship of Theseus"|url=http://2012.tiff-jp.net/news/en/?p=4272|publisher=Tokyo International Film Festival|date=2012-11-05}} the BFI London Film Festival,{{cite web|last=Sawhney|first=Cary|title=Ship of Theseus|url=https://whatson.bfi.org.uk/lff/Online/default.asp?doWork::WScontent::loadArticle=Load&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::article_id=E7D495A2-E0D3-43BE-97C5-5AA2C9E990AF|publisher=BFI London Film Festival}} the Dubai International Film Festival,{{cite web|title=SHIP OF THESEUS MUHR ASIA-AFRICA FEATURE|url=http://dubaifilmfest.com/en/films/detail/ship-of-theseus/23508/2012|publisher=Dubai International Film Festival}} the Mumbai Academy of Moving Images,{{cite journal|title=India shines at Mumbai fest|journal=The Sunday Tribune|date=14 October 2012|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2012/20121014/spectrum/main9.htm}} the Brisbane International Film Festival,{{cite web|title=Ship of Theseus|url=http://tix.biff.com.au/session2_biff.asp?sn=Ship+of+Theseus|publisher=Brisbane International Film Festival}} the Rotterdam International Film Festival{{cite web|title=Ship of Theseus BF-2013|url=http://www.filmfestivalrotterdam.com/en/films/ship-of-theseus/|publisher=International Film Festival Rotterdam}} and the Hong Kong International Film Festival 2013.{{cite web|author=News Desk|title=9 Indian films at Hong Kong International Film Festival 2013|url=http://dearcinema.com/news/9-indian-films-at-hong-kong-international-film-festival-2013/3811|publisher=Dear Cinema}} The film was screened at [[Munich]] and [[Transylvania]] where it won the Best Film and Best Cinematography awards.{{cite journal|author=News Desk|title="Ship of Theseus" to compete at Transylvania International Film Festival 2013|journal=Dear Cinema|date=1 May 2013|url=http://dearcinema.com/news/ship-of-theseus-to-compete-at-transylvania-international-film-festival-2013/3624}} It was also shown at the Sydney Film festival,{{cite web|title=Ship of Theseus|url=http://sff.org.au/public/films/program/features/ship-of-theseus/|publisher=Sydney Film Festival}} where [[Anand Gandhi]] was invited to be a part of the international jury.{{cite journal| author=News Desk|title=Sydney next stop for "Monsoon Shootout" after Cannes|journal=Dear Cinema|date=8 May 2013|url=http://dearcinema.com/news/sydney-next-stop-for-monsoon-shootout-after-cannes/4424}}{{cite web|title=Sydney next stop for "Monsoon Shootout" after Cannes|url=https://www.imdb.com/news/ni53068316/|publisher=imdb.com}} ===Domestic release=== Ship of Theseus was released in theatres across Bangalore, Mumbai, Pune, Delhi, Kolkata and Hyderabad on 19 July 2013. Through the Vote For Your City Campaign, an initiative which saw audiences vote for the film to be released in specific cities, the film was released in Chennai, Kochi, Baroda and Ahmedabad on 26 July 2013. Film was further released in 17 more cities on 2 August. [[Kiran Rao]], after watching the film at Enlighten Films’ Naya Film Festival, came on board to present it to Indian audiences with [[UTV Motion Pictures]] as the distribution partner.{{cite news|last=Jamkhandikar|first=Shilpa|title=Kiran Rao doing her bit for indie film 'Ship of Theseus'|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/06/21/kiran-rao-ship-of-theseus-idINDEE95K07Q20130621|newspaper=Reuters}} ===International release=== On 7 November 2013 the film was released in Australia with actor [[Hugo Weaving]] ([[The Matrix trilogy|''The Matrix'' trilogy]], ''[[Cloud Atlas (film)|Cloud Atlas]]'', [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''Lord of the Rings'' film trilogy]], [[V for Vendetta (film)|''V for Vendetta'']]) presenting.{{cite web| author=Screen Correspondent|title=Hugo Weaving to present Ship Of Theseus in Australia|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/hugo-weaving-to-present-ship-of-theseus-in-australia/1186655/|publisher=The New Indian Express|location=Mumbai | accessdate=25 October 2013}}{{cite web|title=Kiran Rao's Ship of Theseus goes to Australia|url=http://in.movies.yahoo.com/news/kiran-raos-ship-theseus-goes-australia-135746204.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=16 October 2013}}{{cite web|title=Hugo Weaving to present Ship of Theseus in Australia|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-10-16/cinema/43105838_1_theseus-indian-film-ship|publisher=The Times Of India|accessdate=16 October 2013}} ===Online release=== On 15 January 2014 Ship of Theseus was made available for free online viewing and downloading for audiences in India. Soon, the filmmaker tweeted that besides the official free download page, people are also welcome to download the film via unauthorized torrents, in lieu of contributions towards the crowd funding campaign of their next production "Proposition for a Revolution".{{cite web|title=Cineoo Ship of Theasus|url=http://cineoo.com/sot/}} ===Home Video release=== Ship of Theseus has been released on DVD and Blu-ray by Eagle Home Entertainment. The DVD has been released as 2-Disc Edition with bonus disc containing features like Interviews, Bloopers, Making, 2 short films by [[Anand Gandhi]], Deleted scenes, Production stills and a Pin-up poster. The Blu-ray version incorporates all the Bonus features on same disc. Both, DVD and Blu-ray have been meticulously designed by the team at Recyclewala Labs in collaboration with Kriti Media Services (now Cinephile Media), who have mastered and authored them. ===Footage release === In March 2015 entire footage rushes from the film: over 34 hours of footage with keywords, used/ unused annotations and descriptions, was released on the online platform Pad.ma.{{cite web|title=Ship of Theseus footage on Pad.ma|url=https://pad.ma/grid/title/project==Ship_of_Theseus}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== Reviews for the film have been largely positive.{{cite journal|last=Maga|first=Carly|title=Ship of Theseus|journal=Toronto IST|date=6 September 2012|url=http://torontoist.com/2012/09/ship-of-theseus/}}{{cite journal|last=Stewart|first=Kelly Michael|title=Ship Of Theseus|journal=Planet Fury|date=7 September 2012|url=http://www.planetfury.com/content/ship-of-theseus-review}} Some reviewers named it "one of the most significant films to have ever come out of India".{{cite news|last=Gupta|first=Shubhra|title=Back In Business|url=http://www.nfdcindia.com/uploads/post/0975052001357209537.pdf|newspaper=Eye (The Indian Express)|date=2–8 December 2012}}{{cite news|last=Chopra|first=Anupama|title=Newswallah: Bollywood Edition|url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/21/newswallah-bollywood-edition-9/|newspaper=New York Times|date=21 January 2012}} Members of the Critics’ Circle, UK were invited to select and introduce a screening of "the film that changed their life," to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the organisation. The list of 15 films included [[The 400 Blows]], [[Annie Hall]], [[Raging Bull]], [[The Battle of Algiers]] and [[Hamlet]].{{cite journal|last=Cline|first=Rich|title=The Film That Changed My Life: A Celebration of 100 Years of the Critics’ Circle|journal=The Critics' Circle|date=2013-02-27|url=http://www.criticscircle.org.uk/film/?ID=327&PID=4}} The president of the [[British Federation of Film Societies]], [[Derek Malcolm]]{{cite web|last=Chell|first=Jaq|title=Community Exhibitor Survey 2013|url=http://www.bffs.org.uk/export/sites/bffs_site/pdffolder/BFFS_Community_Exhibitor_Survey_2013.doc|publisher=British Federation of Film Societies}} chose Ship of Theseushttps://www.screendaily.com/news/barbican-to-mark-critics-circle-100th/5052174.article. [[Screen International]] commended the film as being, "Cerebral, visually stunning and completely different to anything we’ve seen before from independent Indian cinema… [a film] aiming at art and importance rather than mere profit."{{cite journal|last=Shackleton|first=Liz|title=Anand Gandhi, Ship of Theseus|journal=Screen Daily|date=6 September 2012|url=http://www.screendaily.com/reports/one-on-one/anand-gandhi-ship-of-theseus/5045908.article}} [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] wrote, "Indie Indian cinema has finally come of age on the international fest scene, and no film better demonstrates this than Ship of Theseus." The Canadian film critic, Marc Saint Cyr, after viewing the film at the Rotterdam film festival, in his [[Senses of Cinema]] review said, "unquestionably describes [the film] as [a] true revelation". He also noted the dialogue to be, "consistently gripping, strikingly intelligent, and occasionally laced with surprising humour".{{cite journal|last=Saint-Cyr|first=Marc|title=Along the Tiger Path: The 42nd International Film Festival Rotterdam|journal=Senses Of Cinema|date=March 2013|issue=66|url=http://sensesofcinema.com/2013/festival-reports/along-the-tiger-path-the-42nd-international-film-festival-rotterdam/}} [[The Globe and Mail]] called it "an intellectual, contemplative film", and also pointed out "its occasional tendency to take its abstract ideas on the nature of self-identity and wrap them into neat plot twists can mildly disappoint. A small criticism though." Indian film critic Rajeev Masand in his review wrote, "Languidly paced and lushly filmed, Ship of Theseus is just as rich cinematically, and benefits from terrific performances by each of the protagonists, particularly Kabi whose physical transformation as the ailing monk is a sight to behold."{{cite web|last=Masand|first=Rajeev|title=Deep Waters|url=http://www.rajeevmasand.com/reviews/our-films/deep-waters-2/|publisher=CNN-IBN}} Shubha Shetty-Saha in her five-star review for Mid-Day observed, "Once in a while comes a film like this one, which along with shaking your core, also manages to make you grateful for being a humble part of the audience. 'Ship of Theseus' is one such rare film."{{cite news|last=Shetty-Saha|first=Shubha|title=Movie review: 'Ship of Theseus'|url=http://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/2013/jul/190713-ship-of-theseus-movie-review-bollywood.htm|newspaper=Mid-Day|date=19 July 2013}} An NDTV review opined that, "Ship Of Theseus is an extraordinary achievement. To miss it would be tantamount to missing one of the finest Indian films of recent times."{{cite news|last=Chatterjee|first=Saibal|title=Ship Of Theseus movie review|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/ship-of-theseus-movie-review-843|newspaper=NDTV|date=18 July 2013}} ===Peer response=== [[Shekhar Kapur]] tweeted, "Finally a brilliant new filmmaker emerges in Anand Gandhi with `Ship of Theseus’."{{cite tweet|user=shekharkapur|author=Shekhar Kapur|number=142240072006250497|date=1 December 2011|title=Finally a brilliant new filmmaker emerges in Anand Gandhi with 'Ship of Theseus'. I can go 2 d mountains now}}{{cite journal|last=Kumar Singh|first=Rajesh|title=Toronto selection SHIP OF THESEUS prompts Shekhar Kapoor to retire|journal=Bollywood Trade|date=3 September 2012|url=http://www.bollywoodtrade.com/film-festivals-and-markets/toronto-ship-of-theseus-prompts-shekhar-kapoor-to-retire/index.htm}} Actor [[Hugo Weaving]] said, "Ship Of Theseus is an absolutely rare and profound piece of cinema, full of wonder and enlightenment. Anand Gandhi has proved himself as a groundbreaking filmmaker." [[Anurag Kashyap]] called it, "The most brilliant film to have been made in India in decades. Puts all of us to shame."{{cite web|last=Kashyap|first=Anurag|title=Anurag Kashyap Tweet|url=https://twitter.com/ankash1009/status/148141632259235841|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130626190630/https://twitter.com/ankash1009/status/148141632259235841|dead-url=yes|archive-date=26 June 2013|publisher=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=18 Dec 2011}}{{cite news|title=Ship of Theseus|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-03/bollywood/33562010_1_theseus-ship-film-probes|newspaper=The Times Of India|date=3 September 2012}}{{cite journal|last=Aftab|first=Kaleem|title=Mumbai looms large on Toronto festival screens|journal=The National|date=6 September 2012|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/film/mumbai-looms-large-on-toronto-festival-screens}} Veteran filmmaker [[Shyam Benegal]] deemed it, "A rare film that engages your mind, emotions and senses in equal measure providing the viewer a cinematic experience that is both hugely entertaining and stimulating."{{cite web|last=Benegal|first=Shyam|title=First Thoughts|url=(http://first-thoughts.org/on/Shyam+Benegal/|publisher=First Thoughts}}{{cite tweet|user=shekharkapur|author=Shekhar Kapur|number=263340373546516480|date=30 October 2012|title=@recyclewala was speaking 2 Shyam Benegal abt Ship of Theseus n v both agree that it is d most significant film from India for a long time}} Celebrated documentary filmmaker and polemicist [[Anand Patwardhan]] wrote, "Anand Gandhi’s 'Ship of Theseus' is [[Krzysztof Kieślowski|Kieslowskian]] in scope and delivery, playing between serendipity and causality, but it took me that crucial step further in its rediscovery of the human."{{cite tweet|user=Recyclewala|author=Recyclewala Films|number=307892407905701888|date=2 March 2013|title="Anand Gandhi’s “Ship of Theseus” is Kislowskian in scope and delivery, playing between serendipity and causality,... 1of2}}{{cite tweet|user=Recyclewala|author=Recyclewala Films|number=307892732934893568|date=2 March 2013|title=...but it took me that crucial step further in its rediscovery of the human." - Anand Patwardhan 2of2 #shipoftheseus @recyclewala}} [[Man Booker Prize]] winning author and [[political activist]] [[Arundhati Roy]] wrote, "Ship of Theseus is a profound and fearless film. It is fearlessly contemporary, fearlessly un-noisy and utterly beautifully observed." [[Atul Kulkarni (actor born 1965)|Atul Kulkarni]] called it, "Ship of Theseus. A must, must, must watch. Go with lots of patience and you shall be rewarded with a 'life' time experience ..."Atul Kulkarni on [https://www.facebook.com/atul.kulkarni.100 Facebook] 16 July 2013 [[Dibakar Banerjee]] said, "Ship of Theseus gave me serious doubts about myself as a filmmaker. I seriously introspected for two-three days about my thinking as a filmmaker... This was one film which captivated you, which held you, which mesmerised you without manipulating even once."{{cite web|last=Banerjee|first=Dibakar|title=Dibakar Quote on Ship Of Theseus|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=387396604719510&set=a.354244798034691.1073741825.217535871705585&type=1&theater|publisher=Ship Of Theseus Official Facebook Page}} He also wrote a favourable review on the film and afforded it much praise, encouraging readers to watch the film twice.{{cite news|last=Banerjee|first=Dibakar|title=Dibakar Banerjee: Why you should watch Ship of Theseus twice|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/columns/columns/Dibakar-Banerjee-Why-you-should-watch-Ship-of-Theseus-twice/articleshow/21151933.cms|newspaper=Mumbai Mirror|date=19 July 2013}} Supporting Actress]] |Aida El-Kashef |{{won}} |} ==Themes and interpretations== At the core, the film assumes a, "physical and philosophical interpretation of the Ship of Theseus paradox."{{cite journal|last=Madani|first=Shariq|title=Ship Of Theseus|journal=We Are The Movies|date=14 December 2012|url=http://wearethemovies.com/reviews/ship-of-theseus}} Questions of death, morality and ethics form part of the struggles of each of the three central characters. TimeOut London has called it a "A docu-drama interweaving three stories exploring life in contemporary Mumbai."{{cite web| work=Time Out London|title=Time Out says|date=13 September 2012|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/ship-of-theseus}} Most of the themes are apparent through the film’s characters: "They shared the central themes of idealism, identity, flexibility and the fallibility of conclusive knowing… At the heart, it is a story that celebrates dichotomy, paradox, duality and irony."{{cite web|last=Wylie|first=Addison|title=TIFF 2012: ONE-ON-ONE WITH SHIP OF THESEUS’ ANAND GANDHI|url=http://www.blog.filmarmy.ca/2012/09/11076/|publisher=Film Army}} The film also delves into the nature of relationships – "bound by similarities and challenged by the differences." Anand Gandhi has been further quoted as saying the characters themselves are, "…manifestations of my artistic, ethical, social and philosophical struggles." ===Sight and vision=== The character Aaliya’s visual disability has been described as being central to the idea of the Theseus paradox, wherein one of her parts has been replaced as it was in the mythical ship. It is this replacement that affects her photography and is recognised as the central conflict of the film.{{cite journal|first=J. | last=Hurtado|title=IFFLA 2013 Review: SHIP OF THESEUS [De]Constructs Identity Biologically|journal=Twitch FiIm|date=11 April 2013|url=http://twitchfilm.com/2013/04/iffla-2013-review-ship-of-theseus-deconstructs-identity-biologically.html}} Her regained sight sees her relinquishing her natural intuition.{{cite web|first=K.J. | last=Mullins|title=Review: TIFF Alert — 'Ship of Theseus' is a must see|url=http://digitaljournal.com/article/331679|publisher=Digital Journal}} ===Identity and change=== The filmmaker has been quoted as saying, "There have been a lot of ideas that have fascinated me for a long time. Ship of Theseus has got a very interesting problem of identity and change. The idea that a human changes through a period of time bring us to the question of identity. We also face the question of responsibility in a constantly shifting, changing scenario. The film is a series of interesting problems,"{{cite news|author=Agencies|title=Anand Gandhi's 'Ship Of Theseus' creates waves at Toronto fest|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/anand-gandhis-ship-of-theseus-creates-waves-at-toronto-fest/1000505/0|newspaper=Indian Express|date=10 September 2012}} Nowtoronto.com in its review observed that, "the film measures Mumbai's changing identity, where the modern equivalent of reincarnation could be a kidney transplant."{{cite web|last=Simonpillai|first=Radheyan|title=NOW Review|url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/guides/tiff/2012/listing.cfm?listingid=1262|publisher=NOW Toronto}} ===Personal beliefs=== The monk faced with the dilemma of depending on the very people he is fighting against as a result of his diagnosis, is forced to choose between dying and compromising on his beliefs.{{cite web|last=Oza|first=Shivom|title=A Must, Must Watch!|url=http://www.movietalkies.com/movies/reviews/20784/ship-of-theseus|publisher=Movie Talkies}} His battle with the disease and the notions of those around him makes it an all the more difficult task to stick to his ideals.{{cite web|first=J. | last=Hurtado|title=IFFLA 2013 Review: SHIP OF THESEUS [De]Constructs Identity Biologically|url=http://twitchfilm.com/2013/04/iffla-2013-review-ship-of-theseus-deconstructs-identity-biologically.html|publisher=Twitch Film|date=11 April 2013}}{{cite web|last=Hodgson|first=Matt|title=TIFF 2012 – Ship of Theseus Review|url=http://entertainmentmaven.com/2012/08/30/ship-of-theseus-review/|publisher=Entertainment Maven}} ===Morality and ethics=== The stockbroker’s pursuit of the stolen kidney’s recipient results in his questioning the morality of such a situation. The film also explores the intricacy of morality.{{cite web|agency=[[Barbican Centre]] |title=Ship Of Theseus|url=http://billetto.co.uk/events/shipoftheseus|work=Billetto|date=24 Apr 2013}} It is the moral dilemmas of all three protagonists that tie the seemingly disparate parts of the film together.{{cite book|author1=Bolette Blaagaard|author2=Iris van der Tuin|title=The Subject of Rosi Braidotti: Politics and Concepts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PVc7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA69|date=25 September 2014|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4725-7337-7|pages=69–}} ===Organ donation=== The story of the film depicts changes in lives of people who received organ transplants. The film depicts cornea, liver and kidney transplants.http://m.timesofindia.com/city/ahmedabad/Gujarati-poetry-meets-Greek-paradox/articleshow/21751521.cms ==Literary and cultural allusions and references== The title of the film, 'Ship of Theseus’ alludes to the highly debated [[Ship of Theseus|Theseus’ paradox]] (also referred to as the Theseus’ Ship). The paradox engages in the idea of identity: "If parts of an object are replaced with similar parts, does it remain the same?" The film also refers to ethical issues brought out by applying the Theseus paradox to human beings, "All the cells in a person’s body regenerate entirely in seven years. An individual goes through a shift psychologically, ideologically and physically. Is it still the same person?"{{cite news |title=Of Our Time |url=http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=337980&catid=47 |newspaper=[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]] |date=13 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807053402/http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=337980&catid=47 |archivedate=7 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The young lawyer’s name, Charvaka, is a reference to the ancient Indian atheist [[Cārvāka]], said to have founded the first atheist system of Indian philosophy that assumes various forms of philosophical skepticism and religious indifference. His resulting dialogue with the monk takes on a similar stance. The film also pays homage to the [[Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster]], the satirical religion started in reaction to the introduction of teaching [[creationism]] in schools. The T-shirt donned by the character Charvaka in a scene with the monk reads "[[Pastafarian]]", an allusion to the followers of the [[Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster]].{{cite web| author=Handbags and Lingo|title=Suicide Note|url=http://recyclewala.blogspot.in/2010/10/suicide-note.html|publisher=Anand Gandhi|date=16 October 2010}} During the photographer’s interview she mentions [[Patrick Süskind]]’s novel, ''[[Perfume (novel)|Perfume]]'' and likens her intent with art as being similar to the protagonist from the book "in the quest to capture the essence of everything". An early trailer of the film played a scene deleted from the final cut, which had the character Vinay (Faraz Khan) read out a quote from [[Jean Baudrillard]]’s [[Simulacra and Simulation]]. "Photographic light is not realistic or natural, it is not artificial either..." In the same scene, Aliya, the photographer, also refers to the sphere in a plane-land [[thought experiment]]. The character of Maitreya draws inspiration from thinkers, philosophers and activists such as 19th-century Jain philosopher [[Shrimad Rajchandra]], who was a spiritual guide of [[Mohandas Gandhi]], activist [[Satish Kumar]], environmentalist Abhay Mehta and [[Peter Singer]]. In one of the scenes, the character Dr. Bhargava presents Maitreya with a copy of the Resurgence (''[[Resurgence & Ecologist]]'') magazine that is published and edited by [[Satish Kumar]], known as the man who "walked the planet". Anand Gandhi on the genesis of his film, "The three short stories evolved to fill in the three corners of the classical Indian trinity of Satyam-Shivam-Sunderam (The pursuit of truth, the pursuit of righteousness and the pursuit of beauty)." The TV in the stock broker's hospital ward shows an elderly man cycling through water. It is a reference to an inventor from [[Bihar]] who modified a bicycle to turn it amphibious at the flip of a switch. The fictitious new channel is a nod to the [[National Innovation Foundation]], an autonomous institution that supports grassroots innovations.{{cite journal|last=Gupta|first=Anil|title=Innovations Inc.|journal=Harmony India|date=August 2006|url=http://www.harmonyindia.org/hportal/VirtualPrintView.jsp?page_id=3199}}{{cite news|last=Tewary|first=Amarnath|title=Indian inventor who lives in penury|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7214644.stm|newspaper=BBC|date=3 March 2008}} ==Inventions== The voice over mechanism that the photographer’s camera has installed as a sight-aid, is an in–film invention by [[Anand Gandhi]].{{cite journal|last=Aquino|first=Rowena|title=2013 Indian Film Festival of Los Angeles: Overview|journal=Asia Pacific Arts|date=5 February 2013|url=http://asiapacificarts.usc.edu/w_apa/showarticle.aspx?articleID=18900&AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1}} There currently is no such assistance available for the visually impaired. The monk’s chant was written in [[Prakrit]], specifically for the film, in order to lend credibility to the fictitious religion that he follows, inspired from [[Jainism]] and [[Buddhism]].{{cite web|website=The Single Screen|title=Ship Of Theseus / Anand Gandhi|url=http://thesinglescreen.wordpress.com/tag/ship-of-theseus/}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|1773764|Ship Of Theseus}} * {{Rotten-tomatoes|ship_of_theseus|Ship Of Theseus}} *{{Bollywoodhungama|596658|Ship Of Theseus}} {{National Film Award Best Feature Film}} [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Indian drama films]] [[Category:English-language Indian films]] [[Category:Films shot in Mumbai]] [[Category:Films shot in Himachal Pradesh]] [[Category:Films shot in Rajasthan]] [[Category:Best Feature Film National Film Award winners]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about blind people in India]] [[Category:Films about photographers]] [[Category:Films shot in Stockholm]] [[Category:Films set in Mumbai]] [[Category:Films about organ trafficking]] [[Category:UTV Motion Pictures films]] [[Category:Films featuring a Best Supporting Actress National Film Award-winning performance]] [[Category:Indian avant-garde and experimental films]]

Removing meaningless, un-sourced statement about future SyNAPSE efforts.
revision.text:
[[File:DARPA SyNAPSE 16 Chip Board.jpg|thumb|300px|A [[circuit board]] with a 4×4 array of SyNAPSE-developed chips. Each chip has one million electronic “neurons” and 256 million electronic synapses between neurons. Built on 28nm [[Semiconductor device fabrication|process technology]], the 5.4 billion [[transistor]] chip has one of the [[Transistor count|highest transistor counts]] of any chip ever produced as of 2014.]] '''SyNAPSE''' is a [[DARPA]] program that aims to develop electronic [[neuromorphic]] machine technology, an attempt to build a new kind of [[cognitive computer]] with form, function, and architecture similar to the [[mammalian brain]]. Such [[artificial brain]]s would be used in robots whose [[intelligence]] would scale with the size of the neural system in terms of total number of neurons and synapses and their connectivity.
SyNAPSE is a [[backronym]] standing for ''Systems of Neuromorphic Adaptive Plastic Scalable Electronics''. The name alludes to [[synapse]]s, the junctions between biological neurons. The program is being undertaken by [[HRL Laboratories]] (HRL), [[Hewlett-Packard]], and [[IBM Research]]. In November 2008, IBM and its collaborators were awarded $4.9 million in funding from DARPA while HRL and its collaborators were awarded $5.9 million in funding from DARPA. For the next phase of the project, DARPA added $16.1 million more to the IBM effort while HRL received an additional $10.7 million. In 2011, DARPA added $21 million more to the IBM project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/18/ibm-announces-brainy-computer-chip/?partner=rss&emc=rss|title=I.B.M. Announces Brainy Computer Chip|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref> and an additional $17.9 million to the HRL project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrl.com/hrlDocs/pressreleases/2011/prsRls_110707.html |title=HRL Laboratories : HRL to Develop Neuromorphic Chip for Intelligent Machines in DARPA’s SyNAPSE Program |publisher=Hrl.com |date=2011-07-07 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref> The SyNAPSE team for IBM is led by [[Dharmendra Modha]], manager of IBM's cognitive computing initiative. The SyNAPSE team for HRL is led by Narayan Srinivasa, manager of HRL's Center for Neural and Emergent Systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrl.com/laboratories/cnes/cnes_main.html |title=HRL Laboratories : Laboratories : CNES : Center for Neural & Emergent Systems |publisher=Hrl.com |date=2015-02-26 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref>
The initial phase of the SyNAPSE program developed nanometer scale electronic synaptic components capable of adapting the connection strength between two neurons in a manner analogous to that seen in biological systems ([[Hebbian theory|Hebbian learning]]), and simulated the utility of these synaptic components in core microcircuits that support the overall system architecture.
Continuing efforts will focus on hardware development through the stages of microcircuit development, fabrication process development, single chip system development, and multi-chip system development. In support of these hardware developments, the program seeks to develop increasingly capable architecture and design tools, very large-scale computer simulations of the neuromorphic electronic systems to inform the designers and validate the hardware prior to fabrication, and virtual environments for training and testing the simulated and hardware neuromorphic systems.
==Published product highlights== * clockless operation (event-driven), consumes 70 mW during real-time operation, power density of 20 mW/cm²<ref name="IBM20140807">[http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/44529.wss ''New IBM SyNAPSE Chip Could Open Era of Vast Neural Networks''] IBM, August 7, 2014</ref> * manufactured in Samsung’s 28 nm process technology, 5.4 billion transistors * one million neurons and 256 million synapses networked into 4096 neurosynaptic cores by a [[Network topology|2D array]], all programmable * each core module integrates memory, computation, and communication, and operates in an event-driven, parallel, and fault-tolerant fashion
==Participants== The following people and institutions are participating in the DARPA SyNAPSE program:<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://modha.org/blog/2009/11/post_3.html |title=Dharmendra S Modha's Cognitive Computing Blog: The Cat is Out of the Bag and BlueMatter |publisher=Modha.org |date=2009-11-18 |accessdate=2015-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095855/http://modha.org/blog/2009/11/post_3.html |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
IBM team * [[Stanford University]]: [[Brian Wandell|Brian A. Wandell]], H.-S. Philip Wong * [[Cornell University]]: Rajit Manohar * [[Columbia University Medical Center]]: Stefano Fusi * [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]]: [[Giulio Tononi]] * [[University of California, Merced]]: Christopher Kello * iniLabs GmbH: Tobi Delbruck <ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/41710.wss |title=IBM Research Creates New Foundation to Program SyNAPSE Chips |publisher=ibm.com |date=2013-08-08 |accessdate=2015-06-09}}</ref> * [[IBM Research]]: Rajagopal Ananthanarayanan, Leland Chang, Daniel Friedman, Christoph Hagleitner, Bulent Kurdi, Chung Lam, Paul Maglio, [[Dharmendra Modha]], [[Stuart Parkin]], Bipin Rajendran, Raghavendra Singh
HRL Team * [[HRL Laboratories]]: Narayan Srinivasa, Jose Cruz-Albrecht, Dana Wheeler, Tahir Hussain, Sri Satyanarayana, Tim Derosier, Youngkwan Cho, Corey Thibeault, Michael O' Brien, Michael Yung, Karl Dockendorf, Vincent De Sapio, Qin Jiang, Suhas Chelian * [[Boston University]]: [[Massimiliano Versace]], Stephen Grossberg, Gail Carpenter, Yongqiang Cao, Praveen Pilly * [[Neurosciences Institute]]: Gerald Edelman, Einar Gall, Jason Fleischer * [[University of Michigan]]: Wei Lu * [[University of California-Irvine]]: Jeff Krichmar * [[George Mason University]]: Giorgio Ascoli, Alexei Samsonovich * [[Portland State University]]: Christof Teuscher * [[Stanford University]]: Mark Schnitzer * [http://www.setcorp.com/ Set Corporation]: Chris Long
==See also== *[[TrueNorth]] – IBM chip (introduced mid 2014) boasts of 1 million neurons and 256 million synapses (computing sense); 5.4 billion transistors and 4,096 neurosynaptic cores (hardware).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.darpa.mil/program/systems-of-neuromorphic-adaptive-plastic-scalable-electronics Systems of Neuromorphic Adaptive Plastic Scalable Electronics] * [http://www.neurdon.com/ Neuromorphonics Lab, Boston University] * [http://www.hrl.com/laboratories/cnes/cnes_main.html Center for Neural and Emergent Systems Homepage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120728150603/http://www.hrl.com/index.html HRL Labs Homepage]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Synapse}} [[Category:Electrical engineering]] [[Category:Neurotechnology]] [[Category:DARPA projects]]
